description: You're living through a global pandemic. Don't beat yourself up about extra screen time.
title: How To Be More Mindful About Using Your Phone Amid Coronavirus
title_page: How To Be More Mindful About Using Your Phone Amid Coronavirus | HuffPost Life

But beating ourselves up about extra screen time is of little use right now. Weâ€™re living through a global pandemic, which has brought very real fears to the forefront: concerns about our health, our loved onesâ€™ health, our jobs, the overall economic fallout, loneliness, among others. Plus, our smartphones are our main lifeline to the outside world while weâ€™re physically isolated from many of our family and friends in quarantine.
â€œThese handheld devices are one of our only means of social connection right now, the only way to maintain a sense of community,â€ Jordan Shapiro, author of The New Childhood: Raising Kids to Thrive in a Connected World, told HuffPost.
So yes, weâ€™re using our phones more but it may largely be because of all the texting, calling, FaceTiming and direct messaging weâ€™re doing to stay in touch with loved ones weâ€™d otherwise see in person.
Try to focus less on the number of minutes youâ€™ve logged on your phone and more on how youâ€™re spending that time. Larry Rosen, professor emeritus and past chair of the psychology department at California State University-Dominguez Hills, has been working on a research project looking at both millennialsâ€™ and teenagersâ€™ screen time use before and during quarantine.
â€œIn both cases, screen time has risen but when you look more granularly, you see that a lot of the increase, if not all, is the use of communication tools,â€ Rosen said. â€œSocial media, in particular, is increasing for many teens and millennials as a way to stay in contact and connect with family and friends.â€
â€œIf we just looked at it as an increase in screen time, we would think it was a bad thing,â€ he added. â€œBut in fact, it is a good thing satisfying the human need to connect.â€

Our phones also help us stay informed about the virus and public health guidelines. Theyâ€™re our â€œprimary touchpoint for news and information,â€ Shapiro said.
Getting regular updates is important â€” we need to continue to educate ourselves. But obsessively consuming coronavirus coverage may stoke our fear and anxiety. If the constant barrage of news is affecting your mental state, try cutting back on your media exposure, both on and off your phone, and stick to trusted sources.
For Shapiro, that means limiting the time he spends on Twitter. When sheltering in place began, he found that his feed would often send him into â€œa dreadful spiral of apocalyptic speculation.â€
â€œI recognized that I was looking to digital connection to help me find my footing during this destabilizing time, but some social media made me feel even more helpless and uncertain than I already did,â€ he said. â€œAlternatively, when Iâ€™m texting with friends, video chatting, or scrolling through Instagram, I find it very comforting to see that weâ€™re all still sharing similar experiences.â€
How To Use Your Phone More Mindfully
If the amount of time youâ€™re spending on your phone doesnâ€™t bother you, then you shouldnâ€™t feel pressured to change your habits. However, if excessive screen time is affecting you in negative ways, these tips will help you minimize distress and utilize your devices in a more mindful manner.
When you reach for your phone, pay attention to what youâ€™re thinking or feeling.
Then take note of which websites or apps you gravitate to and why. If youâ€™re experiencing loneliness, then reading seven different projections about how long social distancing could last will probably make you feel worse, whereas DMing a friend might make you feel better.
â€œIf the sites you are using are connecting you with others, that is good,â€ Rosen said. â€œIf they are making you anxious, as they present somewhat scary news 24/7, perhaps that is not a good use of your time.â€
Taking a beat to check in with yourself before and after you pick up your phone will help bring some awareness to what you really need in that moment. Watching a bunch of TikToks may be a great way to to decompress after a demanding day of work; other times, mindless scrolling may be a way to avoid or dull unpleasant emotions that deserve your attention.

I regularly delete Instagram off my phone and then re-download it the next time I want to log in. It only takes an extra 30 seconds, but itâ€™s a small hurdle that stops me from just reflexively opening the app every time I check my phone.

â€œEven before the pandemic, I adjusted my smartphoneâ€™s settings so that only text messages ping, vibrate or chime,â€ Shapiro said. â€œOf course, I still log in to social media and swipe to see who left comments or clicked â€˜like.â€™ But that doesnâ€™t show up on my lock screen, which means I do it on my schedule and on my own terms.â€

â€œMake a list of all the non-digital activities that make you feel good and commit to giving them focused attention,â€ Shapiro said. â€œFor me, books are one thing thatâ€™s important, so I determine how much time I want to spend reading at any given moment â€” how many pages or chapters. And I put my phone aside until Iâ€™m done.â€
Charge your phone somewhere other than the bedroom at night.
â€œYou might consider charging your phone in your bathroom or a separate room to create physical distance from your device,â€ Gupta said.
